qas.question: What is the area called where two plates move apart?
What is the area called where one plate subducts under another?
What type of fault boundary is defined by having widespread powerful earthquakes, as in the state of California?
Whose theory was the theory of continental drift?
The lithosphere moves over which mantle n the theory of plate tectonics?

plausible_answers.text: provided a physical basis for many observations of the solid Earth

qas.question: What did the theory regarding the San Andreas fault do?
What were mid ocean ridges and high regions of geologic features called?
What happened as a result of hydrothermal vents and underwater volcanoes that are transform boundaries?

plausible_answers.text: its ability to combine all of these observations into a single theory of how the lithosphere moves over the convecting mantle

qas.question: What keeps the theory of transform boundaries going?
Why was Wegener's theory important for understanding the lithosphere?
Where in the ocean are volcano arcs located?
What is the mechanism for plate tectonics?
What happens when one plate touches another?

context: The development of plate tectonics <b5_0>provided a physical basis for many observations of the solid Earth<b5_0/>. Long linear regions of geologic features could be explained as <b6_0>plate boundaries<b6_0/>. <b11_0>Mid-ocean ridges<b11_0/>, high regions on the seafloor where hydrothermal vents and volcanoes exist, were explained as <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><a0_3>divergent boundaries<a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>, where two plates move apart. Arcs of volcanoes and earthquakes were explained as <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><a1_3>convergent boundaries<a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>, where one plate subducts under another. <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><a2_3>Transform<a2_1/> boundaries<a2_3/><a2_2/><a2_0/>, such as the San Andreas fault system, resulted in <b7_0>widespread <b13_0>powerful earthquakes<b13_0/><b7_0/>. Plate tectonics also provided a mechanism for <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><a3_3><b9_0>Alfred Wegener<b9_0/><a3_3/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>'s <b12_0>theory of continental drift<b12_0/>, in which the continents move across the surface of the Earth over geologic time. They also provided a driving force for crustal deformation, and a new setting for the observations of structural geology. The power of the theory of plate tectonics lies in <b8_0>its ability to combine all of these observations into <b10_0>a single theory<b10_0/> of how the lithosphere moves over <a4_0>the <a4_1><a4_2><a4_3>convecting<a4_3/><a4_2/> mantle<b8_0/><a4_1/><a4_0/>.
